name: Gatte Ki Sabzi
description: A Rajasthani delicacy made from gram flour (besan) dumplings, steamed and simmered in a spiced yogurt-based gravy. It is rich, tangy, and aromatic, best enjoyed with hot puris, roti, or steamed rice.
preCookingProcess: In a bowl, mix besan, salt, a pinch of turmeric, red chili powder, and 1 tbsp oil.
Add small amounts of water gradually to make a semi-stiff dough.
Divide into small portions and roll into long cylindrical logs (gatte).
Boil water in a pan and add these logs. Cook for 8–10 minutes until firm.
Drain and cut the steamed gatte into small round pieces.

Prepare the yogurt gravy: In a bowl, whisk curd with 1 cup water, turmeric, coriander powder, and 1 tsp besan to prevent curdling. Set aside.
Heat oil in a pan, add cumin seeds and hing. Allow to splutter.
Add ginger paste and green chilies; sauté for 30 seconds.
Add spices and curd mix: Add red chili powder and stir quickly, then mix in the whisked curd mixture while stirring continuously.
Simmer on medium heat for 3–4 minutes until the gravy thickens slightly.
Add and cook the gatte: Add the sliced gatte pieces into the gravy.
Simmer for another 7–8 minutes so that the gatte absorb the flavors.
Finish with a sprinkle of garam masala and chopped coriander.

postCookingProcess: Allow the sabzi to rest for 5 minutes before serving to enhance flavor.
Garnish with more coriander and serve hot with roti or steamed rice.
Add a dollop of ghee on top while serving for authentic Rajasthani taste.
tipsAndTricks: Ensure the curd is whisked well to avoid splitting.
Do not overcook gatte while boiling; they should stay firm.
For richer flavor, shallow fry the steamed gatte before adding to the gravy.
